HARRIERS TO MEET
Hopkins will meet the
Maryland harriers tomorrow
at Homewood field and thereby close the cross-country
schedule. In previous years,
the Jay runners have repeatedly defeated the College
Parkers. However, with several veterans such as Savage,
Shure, Mays, Linsey and
Cooper representing t h e
farmer university, the outcome is by no means definite.
Both teams have met the
same opponent once, Catholic
University having been scheduled and trounced by both.
The score in both instances
was 15-4 against Catholic
University.

Suspicious, most suspicious. Has
the former Hullabaloo staff taken
a correspondence course in salesmanship? Did the NEWS-LETTER
editor play a practical joke? Or
did the printer simply make a
typographical error? In any case
the result is the same.
Hundreds of innocent students,
taking the statements of the NEWSLETTER as published last week in
regard to the subscription to the
Thanksgiving dance next Thursday
acted on the announcement. For
could not the poorest freshman
afford the price of admission—only
one dollar?
Thus many a girl friend received
a ring and accepted the invitation
to "a swell hop" at the Southern
Hotel. But, alas and alack, what
consternation when the NEWSLETTER in the next issue gravely
makes the announcement that the
subscription is two dollars! Either
the date is called off or the family
homestead is mortgaged. The first
is hardly possible, hence the
Thanksgiving dance is very well
attended.

Game
The swimming squad was
recognized as a campus sport
at the last meeting of the A.
A. Board last year. The members of the team will receive
an s H T this year for their
services rendered. Now that
the cross-country season is
over, Coach Hambleton will
be able to devote his entire
time to the swimming squad,
which will be under strict,
orthodox training this year.
Campbell, veteran of last
year's swimming team will be
out again this year with the
rest of the men for the dash
and 440-yard swims
More freshmen managers
and candidates are needed this
year, as the schedule is quite
heavy. Any interested see
Flox in M. E. building.

The Y. M. C. A. evidently has
gained a greater control at the
University of Maryland than it has
at Hopkins despite Levering Hall.
"At a meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
held in the gymnasium on the night
of Monday, November 11, Mr.
David E. Roberts of Baltimore
gave a talk in which the keynote
was the encouragement of the "Y"
in its religious work on the campus.
Mr. Roberts later sang several
hymns and gave the history of the
sacred songs."
We wonder what would happen
at Hopkins if someone had the
nerve to encourage the "Y" in its
religious activity on the campus.

Saturday morning, the annual
Freshman-Sophomore football game
will be played. Both teams have
been taking advantage of every opportunity to practice for the coming
classic. In this year's game the
Freshmen are favored to win.
There has been a regular Freshman
team maintained through the season, coached by Gardiner Mallonee,
former end and captain of the
Hopkins varsity.

Dr. Howard J. Savage, chairman
of the Carnegie Foundation, declared in the November issue of
Sportsmanship that "promises of
ischolarships or nominal and overpaid jobs or other similar advantages taught dishonesty to youth.
No true friend of American sport
and sportsmanship," he continued,
"can be easy in his mind when he
reflects that, the country over,
probably one college athlete in
seven is subsidized."

PARADE

EDITORIALS

MORE OF THE

HE cheer leader was pleased to refer to our editorial of a week
ago as "a lot of hooey." We have no desire to be regarded as
confirmed critics or vigorous opponents of any policy which will
materially aid our own institution. However, if you consider this
Maryland Parade from a sane and logical viewpoint, we believe you
will come to the same conclusion as we already have.
The parade, we are told, is not commercial in its purpose. The fact,
nevertheless, remains that the whole idea of the affair originated not
with an enthusiastic outburst of student spirit, but was instituted at
the request of Mr. Iddins, Business Manager of the University. Connected intimately as he is with the finances of athletics, we cannot
accept the view that his idea in holding the parade was entirely without
regard for the gate receipts. Why should the Business Manager of
the University assume as his task the bolstering of student enthusiasm
for the team? That duty belongs to the cheer leaders and yet this
plan did not emanate from them, but comes through them from
another source.
Genuine spirit, such as was shown in the impromptu celebration
before the St. John's game is an entirely sincere display of loyalty to
our team, but when the whole thing is a carefully planned piece of
propaganda, there is no show of college loyalty involved.
Accepting the assumption that the parade is commercial in purpose,
it tests with the undergraduate body as to whether or not it wishes to be
made an advertising medium. If the student body supports the parade
it will more than likely be like any other parade of former years, for
the taint of commercialization does not intrude on the actual merrymaking. The decision now rests with us underegraduates. We shall
not attempt to dissuade anyone from participating if he is actually
convinced of the sincerity of the project.

THANKSGIVING 1929
HURSDAY, we shall all gather round the festive board to give
thanks for the harvests of another year. This season should be
one of particular rejoicing for our own Hopkins campus, for within a
twelfth-month, momentous doings have taken place in connection with
the growth of the University.
The reins of government of Johns Hopkins have changed hands.
No more wise selection could have been possible than the elevation of
Dr. Ames to the Presidency. He is in every way able to carry on the
work which Gilman, Remsen, and Goodnow have pursued before him.
Let everyone give thanks that we have been so fortunate to have
Dr. Ames as our President.
Momentous strides concerned with the enlargement of the University
have been taken. The Wilmer Institute, the Welch Library, the Department of the History of Medicine and the founding of a Chair of
Chemical Education have all added to the already varied activities of
the University.
The Homewood campus has been physically enriched by the addition
of two new buildings, the Physics Building and Levering Hall. The
Institute for the Study of Law has been assured of a permanent home
and the Carroll Mansion has been restored to its former glory. Gradually, the campus is achieving the dignity of appearance befitting the
magnitude of its accomplishments in more humble quarters.
Even we undergraduates should feel grateful that our own position
in the University remains fairly secure. There are still a sufficient
number of courses to keep us occupied to a reasonable degree. The
New Plan has not completely swallowed us.
With such thoughts let us consume the traditional turkey on Thursday, mindful of the blessings which are ours.
P. W. S.

The Freshmen this year have
played several games. The first of
the season was a victory for the
Frosh over the Friends School
team. The overwhelming defeats
met at the hands of George Washington and Severn School could be
excused by the fact that both of
these teams are unusually strong.
The Freshman line is rather light
but to counterbalance this they
tackle well and seem to be able to
make holes in the offense.
McCabe is a strong kicker both
on the kick-off and on punts. Seitz,
Henderson and Cockey are a trio
of fast, slippery backs.
The Sophomore team has had
some trouble getting together but
has had several practices and a
fairly strong team is resulting. The
men who are pretty sure of playing
are Bernard, Millard, Sigal, Mezzulo, Wood, Millman, Sigelar,
Goldberg, Yudkin and Small. Joe
Bernard was on the varsity squad
last year and the rest of the men
played on last year's Freshman
team. Hershey is coaching the
Sophs.

The Bankers and Financiers
Club is expecting that a number of
well-known bankers, executives and
economists will address them on
problems of current interest in
business. The object of the club is
to make its members aware of what
the world expects of college students entering commercial, financial or industrial fields. -Many of
the speakers are to be New York
bankers, so that the organization
will be able to obtain the latest and
most authentic information from
Wall Street.
Roy Lukanitsch, founder of the
club, says that the thought of organizing such a society occurred to
him when he was on the Mediterranean a year ago. It was thought
that if other universities would establish similar organizations, common interests would develop among
them and an intercollegiate organization, similar to a banking fraternity, would be established. In
the words of Mr. Lukanitsch, "It
is hoped that speakers would inspire members to reach greater
heights in the business world than
have been obtained by those now
looked upon as 'tycoons' of industry and finance.
"Although there are some young
men who are as fortunate as the
son of J. P. Morgan, who on his
twenty-first birthday last year was
given a seat on the New York Stock
Exchange, made a director of the
United States Steel Corporation
and a member of the firm of Morgan & Co., the fact remains that
many executive positions are to be
filled, and, in the majority of cases,
men who have worked their way
from the bottom up by dint of
their unquestioned ability and by the
force of their dynamic personalities
Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of
the board of the National City
Bank of New York, the largest
bank in the country, is an excellent
example of this type—become captains of industry."
The club is planning to hold a
series of weekly luncheons at 12.30
every Tuesday in Room B, Levering Hall. Anyone in the University interested in business in any

FLY WITH CURTISS

For sonic time there has been rising sentiment on the Hopkins
campus against fraternity politics.
Non-fraternity men did not object
strongly to the monopolizing of
class offices and outside activities
by fraternity men and fraternity
pledges; but every man must eat.
\\Then it comes right down to a
non-fraternity man being kept from
his noon-day meal, it is just too
much.
Herewith is a plea for more
noon-day meals for the non-fraternity man. During rushing season
there was many a reason for rushing the poor ignorant frosh, but
of all these causes one was outstanding: If a man worked in the
soda-fountain at Levering Hall, he
was a prize to be fought over.
Here was a man worth his weight
in food. In consequence the widespread influence of the fraternity
has now spread even so far as to

interfere in the meals of the poor
student.
Many and many a time has the
poor non-fraternity meal seeker
stood in the milling croi,vd about
the soda fountain, patiently awaiting a chance to be waited on. On
finally reaching his objective he
calmly states his desire, "One
chocolate milkshake, please." In
the meantime the "pledge" at the
counter espies one of his "pledged"
brothers and the next chocolate
'shake goes to this influential character. Well, the non-fraternity
meal-seeker turns to another sodajerker only to meet the same fate.
He then glances at his watch and
sees it is 5 minutes of 1 o'clock,
just time to make his "lab"; and
he leaves to work the good share
of the afternoon with a gnawing at
his stomach. Non-fraternity men,
arise and stop this outrage! Let the
slogan be "milkshakes for all or no
milkshakes."

until the goal line was crossed.

another march and by the aid of

Suspicious, most suspicious. Has
the former Hullabaloo staff taken
a correspondence course in salesmanship? Did the NEWS-LETTER
editor play a practical joke? Or
did the printer simply make a
typographical error? In any case
the result is the same.
Hundreds of innocent students,
taking the statements of the NEWSLETTER as published last week in
regard to the subscription to the
Thanksgiving dance next Thursday
acted on the announcement. For
could not the poorest freshman
afford the price of admission—only
one dollar?
Thus many a girl friend received
a ring and accepted the invitation
to "a swell hop" at the Southern
Hotel. But, alas and alack, what
consternation when the NEWSLETTER in the next issue gravely
makes the announcement that the
subscription is two dollars! Either
the date is called off or the family
homestead is mortgaged. The first
is hardly possible, hence the
Thanksgiving dance is very well
attended.

The Y. M. C. A. evidently has
gained a greater control at the
University of Maryland than it has
at Hopkins despite Levering Hall.
"At a meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
held in the gymnasium on the night
of Monday, November 11, Mr.
David E. Roberts of Baltimore
gave a talk in which the keynote
was the encouragement of the "Y"
in its religious work on the campus.
Mr. Roberts later sang several
hymns and gave the history of the
sacred songs."
We wonder what would happen
at Hopkins if someone had the
nerve to encourage the "Y" in its
religious activity on the campus.

PARADE

EDITORIALS

MORE OF THE

HE cheer leader was pleased to refer to our editorial of a week
ago as "a lot of hooey." We have no desire to be regarded as
confirmed critics or vigorous opponents of any policy which will
materially aid our own institution. However, if you consider this
Maryland Parade from a sane and logical viewpoint, we believe you
will come to the same conclusion as we already have.
The parade, we are told, is not commercial in its purpose. The fact,
nevertheless, remains that the whole idea of the affair originated not
with an enthusiastic outburst of student spirit, but was instituted at
the request of Mr. Iddins, Business Manager of the University. Connected intimately as he is with the finances of athletics, we cannot
accept the view that his idea in holding the parade was entirely without
regard for the gate receipts. Why should the Business Manager of
the University assume as his task the bolstering of student enthusiasm
for the team? That duty belongs to the cheer leaders and yet this
plan did not emanate from them, but comes through them from
another source.
Genuine spirit, such as was shown in the impromptu celebration
before the St. John's game is an entirely sincere display of loyalty to
our team, but when the whole thing is a carefully planned piece of
propaganda, there is no show of college loyalty involved.
Accepting the assumption that the parade is commercial in purpose,
it tests with the undergraduate body as to whether or not it wishes to be
made an advertising medium. If the student body supports the parade
it will more than likely be like any other parade of former years, for
the taint of commercialization does not intrude on the actual merrymaking. The decision now rests with us underegraduates. We shall
not attempt to dissuade anyone from participating if he is actually
convinced of the sincerity of the project.

THANKSGIVING 1929
HURSDAY, we shall all gather round the festive board to give
thanks for the harvests of another year. This season should be
one of particular rejoicing for our own Hopkins campus, for within a
twelfth-month, momentous doings have taken place in connection with
the growth of the University.
The reins of government of Johns Hopkins have changed hands.
No more wise selection could have been possible than the elevation of
Dr. Ames to the Presidency. He is in every way able to carry on the
work which Gilman, Remsen, and Goodnow have pursued before him.
Let everyone give thanks that we have been so fortunate to have
Dr. Ames as our President.
Momentous strides concerned with the enlargement of the University
have been taken. The Wilmer Institute, the Welch Library, the Department of the History of Medicine and the founding of a Chair of
Chemical Education have all added to the already varied activities of
the University.
The Homewood campus has been physically enriched by the addition
of two new buildings, the Physics Building and Levering Hall. The
Institute for the Study of Law has been assured of a permanent home
and the Carroll Mansion has been restored to its former glory. Gradually, the campus is achieving the dignity of appearance befitting the
magnitude of its accomplishments in more humble quarters.
Even we undergraduates should feel grateful that our own position
in the University remains fairly secure. There are still a sufficient
number of courses to keep us occupied to a reasonable degree. The
New Plan has not completely swallowed us.
With such thoughts let us consume the traditional turkey on Thursday, mindful of the blessings which are ours.
P. W. S.

men who are pretty sure of playing

Goldberg, Yudkin and Small. Joe
Bernard was on the varsity squad
last year and the rest of the men
played on last year's Freshman
team. Hershey is coaching the
Sophs.

The Bankers and Financiers
Club is expecting that a number of
well-known bankers, executives and
economists will address them on
problems of current interest in
business. The object of the club is
to make its members aware of what
the world expects of college students entering commercial, financial or industrial fields. -Many of
the speakers are to be New York
bankers, so that the organization
will be able to obtain the latest and
most authentic information from
Wall Street.
Roy Lukanitsch, founder of the
club, says that the thought of organizing such a society occurred to
him when he was on the Mediterranean a year ago. It was thought
that if other universities would establish similar organizations, common interests would develop among
them and an intercollegiate organization, similar to a banking fraternity, would be established. In
the words of Mr. Lukanitsch, "It
is hoped that speakers would inspire members to reach greater
heights in the business world than
have been obtained by those now
looked upon as 'tycoons' of industry and finance.
"Although there are some young
men who are as fortunate as the
son of J. P. Morgan, who on his
twenty-first birthday last year was
given a seat on the New York Stock
Exchange, made a director of the
United States Steel Corporation
and a member of the firm of Morgan & Co., the fact remains that
many executive positions are to be
filled, and, in the majority of cases,
men who have worked their way
from the bottom up by dint of
their unquestioned ability and by the
force of their dynamic personalities
Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of
the board of the National City
Bank of New York, the largest
bank in the country, is an excellent
example of this type—become captains of industry."
The club is planning to hold a
series of weekly luncheons at 12.30
every Tuesday in Room B, Levering Hall. Anyone in the University interested in business in any

FLY WITH CURTISS

For sonic time there has been rising sentiment on the Hopkins
campus against fraternity politics.
Non-fraternity men did not object
strongly to the monopolizing of
class offices and outside activities
by fraternity men and fraternity
pledges; but every man must eat.
\\Then it comes right down to a
non-fraternity man being kept from
his noon-day meal, it is just too
much.
Herewith is a plea for more
noon-day meals for the non-fraternity man. During rushing season
there was many a reason for rushing the poor ignorant frosh, but
of all these causes one was outstanding: If a man worked in the
soda-fountain at Levering Hall, he
was a prize to be fought over.
Here was a man worth his weight
in food. In consequence the widespread influence of the fraternity
has now spread even so far as to

interfere in the meals of the poor
student.
Many and many a time has the
poor non-fraternity meal seeker
stood in the milling croi,vd about
the soda fountain, patiently awaiting a chance to be waited on. On
finally reaching his objective he
calmly states his desire, "One
chocolate milkshake, please." In
the meantime the "pledge" at the
counter espies one of his "pledged"
brothers and the next chocolate
'shake goes to this influential character. Well, the non-fraternity
meal-seeker turns to another sodajerker only to meet the same fate.
He then glances at his watch and
sees it is 5 minutes of 1 o'clock,
just time to make his "lab"; and
he leaves to work the good share
of the afternoon with a gnawing at
his stomach. Non-fraternity men,
arise and stop this outrage! Let the
slogan be "milkshakes for all or no
milkshakes."

In place of the second team
which they had been using, Mt. St.
Joseph ran in their first team for
the second half, while Hopkins'
second team went in.
Hopkins kicked off and the Mt.
St. Joseph team started a march
down the field which did not stop
until the goal line was crossed.
They drop-kicked for the extra
point. Score, 14-8.
The freshmen received and made
two first downs before they were
forced to kick. Mt. St. Joe started
another march and by the aid of
two passes scored again. This time
the try for point was blocked, making the score 20-8. Again Hopkins
received and this time started a
march of their own. They made
two first downs in five plays. On
,the next play Leitz wriggled
through tackle for 10 yards, and
on the following play 10 yards
more was gained, only to lose the
ball on a fumble.
